Posts.Content: May 24, 2009 01:10PM emtesla wrote: A causal link was never established between use of deoderant/antiperspirant and developing breast CA; that started because a higher percentage of breast CA was being diagnosed in the US, where a higher percentage of women use deoderant vs. European women. The thing is, more women in the US get mammograms, which can give the appearance that breast CA is more prevalent, but it is actually just that it is more frequently detected. It is really important to remember that a "cause and effect" link has to be established, not just a "correlational" link. The mantra of good research is "correlation does not prove causation". That said, what matters most is what you are comfortable doing, so perhaps a visit to a holistic or organic store might give you more options.

Posts.Content: May 3, 2009 11:58AM emtesla wrote: Otter, you know your imaging! There are a few additional advantages to digital imaging. Skin folds near the axilla can be adjusted for; no more lost films so easier comparison, and a lot of places that use digital imaging are also using CAD (computer aided diagnosis aka Second Sight), which is an additional step that can sometimes help find very subtle abnormalities. But, like you said, a dense breast is a dense breast, and although digital imaging allows the radiologist to better "window" the image by making it darker or brighter, it doesn't mean that the breast was better penetrated by the x-ray beam. Eldub, you bring up some great points as well. My only other suggestion is to make sure that any mammograms are done at an ACR (American College of Radiography) accredited site; the techs and equipment have to meet a very high standard, and the radiologists have to read over a certain number of mammograms a year to maintain their proficiency. The important (and frustrating) part is that all of these different modalities show different information. Calcifications show up well on a mammogram, but not so well on a MRI or US. US is great at showing if an area is solid or fluid, and MRI can show if an area enhances with contrast possibly indicating an abnormality, but there is so much information on a MRI that it can sometimes be difficult to say with confidence that an area is benign or suspicious. Sometimes it is only by using multiple modalities that a course of treatment can be decided upon. In the interest of full disclosure, I am an x-ray tech who used to do mammography but now I do MRI.

Posts.Content: May 2, 2009 10:35PM emtesla wrote: Hi Elisa That is my name, too! The way the letters work is that each mammogram that is read is assigned a BIRADS classification. It is a shorthand way to describe what the radiologist found on the initial report. What her letter probably says is something like the radiologist found some inconclusive areas and additional imaging is needed. Like everyone has said, 80% of these cases are normal non-cancerous changes in the breast tissue. I know this is scary, but stay positive, okay?
